awd_titl_txt: Understanding The Impact of Product Dissection on Design Innovation and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Product dissection, or the systematic disassembly of products, is used as a means to help designers discover the inner workings of products and inspire new design ideas. While product dissection has been widely adopted in both engineering education and industry, there are many widely varying approaches of dissecting products for encouraging creativity and design learning. However, almost all dissection activities currently require products to be dissected physically which limits the utility of these activities due to the cost of the materials, space requirements, and the effort required to dissect the product. This award supports fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the development of cognitive models of product dissection innovation and learning practices. These new models will enable the development of sustainable, low-cost dissection practices that promote, rather than inhibit, novel idea generation in engineering education and industry. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. society and economy. This research involves several disciplines including engineering, psychology and management. The multidisciplinary approach will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and positively impact engineering education.
 
The new cognitive models developed through this award can overcome several limitations of existing dissection practices, ranging from design fixation, reduced innovation potential, and increased cognitive load. However, some scientific barriers are yet to be overcome to realize the full application potential of product dissection activities for design innovation and learning. This research is to fill the knowledge gap on the factor(s) of product dissection that support the creative potential of students and practicing designers. The research team will perform controlled experimental investigations to understand the impact of the medium of dissection, the complexity of the product selected for dissection, the cognitive load requirements of the activity, and the impact of team training.  Based on the results of these experiments, cognitive models of the impact of these factors on design learning and innovation will be established.

por.por_cntn:
It is in the nature of engineers to take apart products in order to satisfy their inherent curiosity of the world. Discovering the inner workings of products can serve to teach and inspire, and engineers often practice this "dissection" in order to gain design insights and identify opportunities for redesign.  In fact, product dissection has been widely integrated throughout industry and academia as a way to understand core concepts and gain insights into competitors practices. However, the study of dissection and its impact on design creativity and learning had received limited attention in design research. This was problematic because prior work suggests that contact with examples early in the design process, such as through dissection activities, can cause designers to fixate on the example provided thereby inhibiting their ability to produce creative ideas.

The goal of this three-year investigation was to provide evidence on how variations in product dissection activities impact creativity and learning in engineering design in order to best integrate these practices into engineering education and industry to foster creativity and innovation. Towards this end, studies were conducted with engineering design students to identify how the product dissected (similar or different from the design task), the complexity of the product dissected (simple or complex), and how the product was dissected (virtual or physical), impacts a student's ability to both understand how the product works and produce new ideas for a design task.  

Through this research, we learned that while virtual dissection was more efficient than its physical counterpart, there was no difference in the learning gains or the creativity of ideas developed between these two dissection environments.  When exploring the impact of the type of virtual dissection performed (computer, iPad or Virtual Reality), we identified that there was no change in student learning benefits; however students perceived that their learning was greater in the virtual reality system. This is significant for engineering education because it suggests that virtual dissection can successfully be used to replace physical dissection practices and that dissection practices are useful in the context of engineering education. In other words, these findings provide a better understanding of the extent to which virtual activities can replicate physical activities in engineering classroom. The results of this research also indicated that the product selected for dissection (both its complexity and its similarity to the design task) impacted student learning and their confidence in their ability to be creative. These findings indicate the importance of the product selected for dissection.

These findings were used to develop and evaluate the effectiveness of dissection modules geared at increasing student learning and creativity in engineering education. These modules are available through a free online platform - https://www.engr.psu.edu/productdissection/. Through investigations in the engineering classroom, we found that students felt the product dissection modules were useful, valuable, and enjoyable and that students had a positive sentiment towards the dissection module. The modules were distributed to engineering educators through a workshop held by the investigators at the American Society for Engineering Education First-Year Engineering Experiences conference.  

The results from this proposal have advanced the field of engineering by developing an understanding of the impact of variations of dissection practices on design creativity and learning. These results also provide an understanding of the extent to which virtual activities can replicate physical activities in engineering education - creating a foundation for transferring hands-on engineering activities into virtual environments. In addition, the free, interactive website created through the research greatly reduces the costs of dissection activities (e.g. cost of product, tools, and environment) allowing for students in lower-income schools to be exposed to engineering design through the dissection activities. This early exposure to engineering design has to potential to help increase awareness and interest in the engineering discipline. In addition, the open-source nature of our 3D models and training modules allow researchers from around the world to conduct experiments on example-based design practices in the same environment, which will increase research validity and revolutionize our understanding of the impact of example-based design practices.
